True reality is devoid of characteristics and also devoid of nature, which is called nonexistent yet existent. Since there is the true nature of existence, it is said to be not nonexistent, as explained in the BodhisattvabhÅ«mi-sÅ«tra.

Moreover, true reality is called existent in contrast to nonexistence, and is called nonexistent in contrast to existence. In reality, it transcends both existence and nonexistence, and is called neither existent nor nonexistent.
Because of causes and conditions, dharmas arise does not contradict conventional reality.

Although it is said in truth that [dharmas] are neither existent nor nonexistent, in accordance with the world, it is always said that effects are obtained from causes. Therefore, it is said that because of conditions, dharmas arise.
This refers to the arising of pleasant and painful dharmas due to the causes and conditions of good and evil.
No self, no creator, and no experiencer refers to being able to speak of true reality.
This clarifies that the emptiness of beings is the truth of ultimate reality.
Within the truth of ultimate reality, there is no self or person to be found, and it is called no-self.
Because there is no self, there is no person who creates causes, and it is called no creator;
There is no person who experiences results, and it is called no experiencer.

The karma of good and evil is also not lost means that although it does not exist within the truth of ultimate reality, it always has the function of attracting results in the conventional truth, and therefore it is said to be not lost.

First under the Bodhi tree, with power subduing Mara refers to the expedient means for attaining Buddhahood.
The Buddha attained enlightenment relying on a tree, and that tree is sometimes called the Bodhi tree, sometimes the Way tree, and sometimes the Bodhi tree.
Attaining Buddhahood under the tree is called the Bodhi tree, attaining the Way under the tree is called the Way tree, and realizing the fruit of Bodhi under the tree is called the Bodhi tree.
Before attaining Buddhahood, one relies on this tree, hence it is said first under the Bodhi tree.

At that time, Mara feared that the Buddha would attain enlightenment and came to disturb the Bodhisattva. The Bodhisattva then entered the meditation of supreme kindness and subdued Mara with spiritual powers, called with power subduing Mara.
Also, using the power of kindness to make Mara submit is called with power subduing Mara.
